# PR Summary
Fix #13201

## PR Context

If we are at `Temp:\`, `$PWD.Path` returns `Temp:\`, unknown PSDrive for Windows PowerShell.
Instead, `Convert-Path -Path $PWD.Path` returns a standard FileSystem path like `C:\Users\me\AppData\Local\Temp\`. It can be handled by Windows PowerShell.

Adding new Virtualization-Based Security (VBS) feature names to the Get-ComputerInfo cmdlet. This commit addresses issue #16357

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

This PR adds supported Virtualization-Based Security (VBS) feature names to the Get-ComputerInfo cmdlet. This PR addresses issue #16357.

Thank you for your consideration.

## PR Context

Upon merging this PR, users of Windows Defender Application Control (WDAC) will benefit more greatly from Get-ComputerInfo in that it will present all available VBS features in a human-readable fashion, as Get-ComputerInfo intended. The feature names added in this PR will also offer parity with the feature names presented in the `msinfo32.exe` UI.

Note: this change would also ideally need to be backported to Windows PowerShell.

### Steps to reproduce

Run the script:
```PowerShell
[Console]::CursorVisible = $false
Write-Host "Before wp - " -NoNewLine
[Console]::CursorVisible
0..10 | % {
    Write-Progress -Activity test -Status test -PercentComplete $_
    Start-Sleep -s 0.1
}
Write-Host "After wp - " -NoNewLine
[Console]::CursorVisible
```

### Expected behavior

`Write-Progress` shouldn't affect the state of `CursorVisible`


### Actual behavior

```PowerShell
PS > .\script.ps1
Before wp - False
After wp - True
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```PowerShell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

The majority of Linux shells let you use !! as an alias for the last run command.  This is useful for many things, like using `sudo !!` to run the previous command as root.  I believe this could also be very useful in PowerShell.

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Upgrading package reference for System.Management.Automation to version 7.2, I got the compiler error CS1061:
```
'IScriptExtent' does not contain a definition for 'File' and no accessible extension method 'File' accepting a first argument of type 'IScriptExtent' could be found (are you missing a using directive or an assembly reference?)
```
due to this line:
```
// statement is an instance of StatementAst
writer.WriteLine("### File: {0}", System.IO.Path.GetFileName(statement.Extent.File));
```

I have confirmed that the property exists in the interface while running PowerShell so it looks like this is just omitted from the reference assembly:
```
[System.Management.Automation.Language.IScriptExtent].GetProperty('File')
```

### Expected behavior

```console
No Error
```


### Actual behavior

```console
CS1061: 'IScriptExtent' does not contain a definition for 'File' and no accessible extension method 'File' accepting a first argument of type 'IScriptExtent' could be found (are you missing a using directive or an assembly reference?)
```


### Error details

_No response_

```powershell
NA. Referencing System.Management.Automation version 7.2.0
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

In a nutshell, support colored comand output the way `ls` does on *nix. That woud be a minimum. Then this can be improved during the feature design.

```
 -C                    list entries by columns
      --color[=WHEN]   colorize the output; WHEN can be 'always' (default
                       if omitted), 'auto', or 'never'; more info below
...
Using color to distinguish file types is disabled both by default and
with --color=never.  With --color=auto, ls emits color codes only when
standard output is connected to a terminal.  The LS_COLORS environment
variable can change the settings.  Use the dircolors command to set it.
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

In practice, `catch [System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException] { ... }` seems to behave the same as an _unqualified_ `catch` block.

That is, it catches _any_ exception - even those _not_ derived from `System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException`

```powershell
try { throw ([System.ArgumentException] 'foo') }
catch [System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException] { 'What are you doing here? ' }
```

### Expected behavior

The exception thrown should surface as a script-terminating error, because its type isn't derived from `System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException`, so the `catch` block should not be entered.


### Actual behavior

`'What are you doing here?'` is output, because the `catch` block was unexpectedly entered.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-rc.1
```


### Visuals

_No response_

# PR Summary

This change allows users to tab complete both named and numerical values for the Scope parameter. This PR addresses issue #8106. This applies to all cmdlets that use the scope parameter as specified by the issue, including:
- Remove-PSDrive
- Get-PSDrive
- New-PSDrive
- Clear-Variable
- Get-Variable
- Remove-Variable
- Set-Variable
- Get-Alias
- Export-Alias
- Import-Alias
- New-Alias
- New-Variable
- Remove-Alias
- Set-Alias

## PR Context

This change modifies the [System.Management.Automation.CommandCompletion]::CompleteInput method to work appropriately with the Scope parameter. For example, if it is called in a certain scope with no specific word to complete (suppose 0, 1, and 2 are valid scope values), the method will return 0, 1, and 2, along with "global", "local", and "script". These latter three values may always be returned, regardless of the current scope.

A method CompletionCompleters.cs:NativeCompletionScope was added (with a helper method CompletionCompleters.cs:CompleteScope), and the implementation details are similar to the existing NativeCompletion* methods. 

Note that when users actually perform the tab completion in Powershell, some scope numbers that are out of range are returned. This is an issue with how the results from the CompleteInput method are used, and would involve future changes.

The added test checks that the CompleteInput method appropriately tab-completes Scope values at the script level as well as the single, double, and triple nested function level. In addition, each cmdlet listed above is tested for this.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Setting [`Set-StrictMode`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/set-strictmode) to a specific `-Version` level automatically implies that *all prior* prohibitors are enabled. Meaning that there is no way just select for a recent prohibitor (e.g. "*out of bounds or unresolvable array indexes*") without also selecting a earlier prohibitor (e.g. "*references to uninitialized variables*").

A `-Modes` parameter that supports certain prohibit flags, e.g.:
```PowerShell
[Flags()] enum StrictModes {
    ProhibitReferencesToUninitializedVariables = 1
    ProhibitReferencesToNonExistentProperties = 2
    ProhibitUseOfCallingMethodSyntax = 4
    ProhibitUnresolvableArrayIndexes = 8
    ProhibitOmittingWriteOutput = 16
}
```
will avoid that.
The lack of selective prohibitors also holds back the future extensions of the `Set-StrictMode` cmdlet as e.g. [`#15781`Strict Write-Output](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15781).


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

```
$ExecutionContext.SessionState.InvokeCommand.InvokeScript(
  <# script #> 'Test-Path C:',
  <# useNewScope #> $false,
  <# pipelineResultTypes #> 'All', # anything other than 'Output' and/or 'Error'
  <# input #> $null, # or @()
  <# params arguments #> @()
)
```

Obviously I can see now that this is not intended to be supported, but the exception seems like it could do with some improvement.

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/ef69fdafc41017661203fde8ed3ab77414f5e14e/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/MshCmdlet.cs#L841-L845

### Expected behavior

```console
# Initially I expected this to run the script. It is documented on msdn that this is not supported but the error message was definitely not helpful in discerning that.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Exception calling "InvokeScript" with "5" argument(s): "Cannot perform operation because operation "NewNotImplementedException at offset 34 in file:line:column <filename unknown>:0:0
" is not implemented."
```


### Error details

```console
# Huge error that doesn't explain the actual problem, which is that only Error and Output are supported for PipelineResultTypes
```

body:
### Steps to reproduce

Install/upgrade Powershell on CentOS 7.9 (ours was handled by Puppet) to `7.2.0`, which was released today to the `https://packages.microsoft.com/rhel/7/prod/` yum repo:
```
Nov  5 13:55:37 Docker-1 yum[23463]: Updated: powershell-7.2.0-1.rh.x86_64
Nov  5 13:55:37 Docker-1 puppet-agent[23019]: (/Stage[main]/Profile::Base::Linux::jenkins_node/Exec[install pwsh]/returns) executed successfully (corrective)
```

Invoke `New-PSSession` to Windows DC:
```
PS> New-PSSession -ComputerName dc-01.mydomain.com -Credential $cred -Authentication Negotiate
```

### Expected behavior

Successful connection, as with `7.1.5`:
```console
PS> New-PSSession -ComputerName dc-01.mydomain.com -Credential $cred -Authentication Negotiate

 Id Name            Transport ComputerName    ComputerType    State         ConfigurationName     Availability
 -- ----            --------- ------------    ------------    -----         -----------------     ------------
  1 Runspace1       WSMan     englab-dc-01.c… RemoteMachine   Opened        Microsoft.PowerShell     Available
```


### Actual behavior

Failed connection:
```console
PS> New-PSSession -ComputerName dc-01.mydomain.com -Credential $cred -Authentication Negotiate
New-PSSession: This parameter set requires WSMan, and no supported WSMan client library was found. WSMan is either not installed or unavailable for this system.
```


### Error details

Additional error from `/var/log/messages`:
```console
Nov  5 13:59:02 Docker-1 powershell[24057]: (7.2.0:D:80) [TransportError:None.Open.Error] Runspace Id: WSManAPIDataCommon.ctor Pipeline Id: WSManInitialize. WSMan reported an error with error code: -2146233052.#012 Error message: Unable to load shared library 'libpsrpclient' or one of its dependencies. In order to help diagnose loading problems, consider setting the LD_DEBUG environment variable: liblibpsrpclient: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory#012 StackTrace:    at System.Management.Automation.Remoting.Client.WSManNativeApi.WSManInitialize(Int32 flags, IntPtr& wsManAPIHandle)#012   at System.Management.Automation.Remoting.Client.WSManClientSessionTransportManager.WSManAPIDataCommon..ctor()
```

If I downgrade Powershell back to `7.1.5` with `yum downgrade`, it works again. Upgrade to `7.2.0`, it breaks.


### Environment data

```powershell
PS /home/jjarzynka_a> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0
OS                             Linux 3.10.0-1160.42.2.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Sep 7 14:49:57 UTC 2021
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
### Steps to reproduce

I am trying to use the AES algorithm in GCM mode for code that works on PowerShell Core. When I try to use the AesGcm class on Mac OS, the pwsh process crashes.


Steps to reproduce:
Run the following script on Mac OS (PowerShell version 7.1.5):

```powershell
$aes2 = [System.Security.Cryptography.AesGcm]::new([byte[]]::new(32))
```

### Expected behavior
`$aes2` to contain an object that implements AES-GCM (or if it is not supported on this platform - report an error - not crash the process)



### Actual behavior
The PowerShell process was terminated.

```console
No usable version of libssl was found
zsh: abort      pwsh
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.5
OS                             Darwin 21.1.0 Darwin Kernel Version 21.1.0: Wed…
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

I have tried installing PowerShell using the direct download as well as homebrew - that does not seem to make a difference.

I have tried to install OpenSSL, but either I didn’t do it correctly or it does not have an effect on PowerShell.

I have tested this on Mac OS version 10, 11, 12 (Intel-virtualised) - does not seem to make a difference. 

I have tested the `[System.Security.Cryptography.ECDiffieHellman]` type and that works as expected (which according to the [.Net documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/security/cross-platform-cryptography) also require OpenSSL as far as I understand it).


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I would like to place a character formatted with an  ANSI escape sequence in a BufferCell, but the constructor only takes a char:

`BufferCell(Char, ConsoleColor, ConsoleColor, BufferCellType)`

Even though only being a single character when rendered, I would have to use a string to represent it when using ANSI escape sequences. Further, in my case, I would use the escape sequence to format the color, thus having to provide the two ConsoleColors would either be superfluous (if ignored) or detrimental (if overriding the ANSI coloring), so I would like a constructor like this:

`BufferCell(String, BufferCellType)`

Which should take the output resulting from the string and put it in the Buffercell, leaving colors alone.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

- String is a poor format for what is supposed to be only one character. I propose that any implementation and documentation reflects that only the _first renderable_ character from the string will be used.

- Apart from allowing ANSI formatting, this should allow using Unicode escape sequences (e.g., ``"`u{1F600}"``) in BufferCells.

### Steps to reproduce

```
(Write-Output 1) -is [pscustomobject]  # unexpectedly True, although .GetType() returns Int32
(1) -is [pscustomobject]  # False, as expected

$x = Write-Output 1
$x -is [pscustomobject]  # also unexpectedly True
$y = 1
$y -is [pscustomobject]  # False, as expected
```

The issue seems reproducible in both `PowerShell 5.1` and `PowerShell Core 7.2.0-rc.1`.

### Expected behavior

```console
False each time (`Int32` is not a `pscustomobject`).
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PowerShell seems to think any object returned by `Write-Output` is somehow also `pscustomobject`.
```

Result of this issue is we can have a pair of "almost exactly the same" objects, but one of them thinks it's also a `pscustomobject`:

```
$x = 1
$y = echo $x  # I'd assume $y is the exact same thing as $x here...

$x -is [pscustomobject]
$y -is [pscustomobject]  # ...but it's not, because these two checks return different things.
```

### Steps to reproduce

This may be as well just a documentation issue, but so far I'm more inclined it's either a bug or a misfeature on behalf of the cmdlet where it just completely omits any and all `$null` values piped from the pipeline. The help topics do not appear to govern the behaviour of the cmdlet in regards to null values specifically, but do note that generally `$null` does participate in the pipeline as regular values, quoting `ForEach-Object` executing its `Process` blocks for them indiscriminately as an example, and I believe `Select-Object` should be no exception here.

I need to pick at most one value from an external source, and null values are OK. Naturally I wrote something along the lines of `$data | select -First 1 | Get-StuffDone` (`Get-StuffDone` there is a long chain of commands **including one that assigns a default value for null values**) only to discover my change broke everything as the pipeline gets abruptly interrupted right off the start.

### Expected behavior

```pwsh
PS> @($null, 1) * 10 | Select-Object | ForEach-Object { "OUTPUT: |$_|" }
```
```
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|

OUTPUT: |1|

OUTPUT: |1|

OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: ||
OUTPUT: |1|
```

### Actual behavior

```pwsh
PS> @($null, 1) * 10 | Select-Object | ForEach-Object { "OUTPUT: |$_|" }
```
```OUTPUT: |1|

OUTPUT: |1|

OUTPUT: |1|
OUTPUT: |1|

OUTPUT: |1|
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

On a system that has support for Windowd Defender Application Control (WDAC), `Get-ComputerInfo` will return available Virtualization-Based Security (VBS) features via the `DeviceGuardAvailableSecurityProperties` property. The [DeviceGuardHardwareSecure](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/0f2f23f67a2c3ec53cf82c8d1a67b479f62934e4/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management/commands/management/GetComputerInfoCommand.cs#L3670-L3691) enum does not support the latest features, however.

To reproduce, run the following:

```powershell
Get-ComputerInfo | Select-Object -ExpandProperty DeviceGuardAvailableSecurityProperties
```

The issue is surfaced when returned values are output as numbers instead of human-readable strings.

To fix the issue, all that is needed is to add the following enum values to [DeviceGuardHardwareSecure](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/0f2f23f67a2c3ec53cf82c8d1a67b479f62934e4/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management/commands/management/GetComputerInfoCommand.cs#L3670-L3691):

```csharp
        /// <summary>
        /// UEFI Code Readonly.
        /// </summary>
        UEFICodeReadonly = 5,

        /// <summary>
        /// SMM Security Mitigations 1.0.
        /// </summary>
        SMMSecurityMitigations = 6,

        /// <summary>
        /// Mode Based Execution Control.
        /// </summary>
        ModeBasedExecutionControl = 7
```

These human-readable values were obtained from `msinfo32.exe` (System Summary->Virtualization-based security Available Security Properties)

The `Get-ComputerInfo` cmdlet obtains this information from the `Win32_DeviceGuard` class which was updated to support additional enum values:

```
PS> ([WmiClass] 'root\Microsoft\Windows\DeviceGuard:Win32_DeviceGuard').GetText('mof')
[dynamic: ToInstance, provider("Win32_DeviceGuard"): ToInstance, locale(1033)]
class Win32_DeviceGuard
{
        [key] string InstanceIdentifier;
        string Version;
        [ValueMap{"1", "2", "3", "4", "5", "6", "7"}: ToSubClass, ArrayType("Indexed"): DisableOverride ToSubClass] uint32 RequiredSecurityProperties[];
        [ValueMap{"1", "2", "3", "4", "5", "6", "7", "8"}: ToSubClass, ArrayType("Indexed"): DisableOverride ToSubClass] uint32 AvailableSecurityProperties[];
        [ValueMap{"0", "1", "2"}: ToSubClass] uint32 VirtualizationBasedSecurityStatus;
        [ValueMap{"1", "2", "3", "4"}: ToSubClass, ArrayType("Indexed"): DisableOverride ToSubClass] uint32 SecurityServicesConfigured[];
        [ValueMap{"1", "2", "3", "4", "5"}: ToSubClass, ArrayType("Indexed"): DisableOverride ToSubClass] uint32 SecurityServicesRunning[];
        [ValueMap{"0", "1", "2"}: ToSubClass] uint32 CodeIntegrityPolicyEnforcementStatus;
        [ValueMap{"0", "1", "2"}: ToSubClass] uint32 UsermodeCodeIntegrityPolicyEnforcementStatus;
        boolean VirtualMachineIsolation;
        [ValueMap{"1", "2"}: ToSubClass, ArrayType("Indexed"): DisableOverride ToSubClass] uint32 VirtualMachineIsolationProperties[];
};
```

This issue is also applicable to Windows PowerShell.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Get-ComputerInfo | Select-Object -ExpandProperty DeviceGuardAvailableSecurityProperties

BaseVirtualizationSupport
SecureBoot
DMAProtection
SecureMemoryOverwrite
UEFICodeReadonly
SMMSecurityMitigations
ModeBasedExecutionControl
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Get-ComputerInfo | Select-Object -ExpandProperty DeviceGuardAvailableSecurityProperties

BaseVirtualizationSupport
SecureBoot
DMAProtection
SecureMemoryOverwrite
5
6
7
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.5
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.5
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0â€¦}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Currently, `Enter-PSSession` only behaves as expected - _synchronously_ entering an interactive remote session - when called _directly_ from an _interactive_ PowerShell session.

By contrast, it fails obscurely when called via `pwsh -Command` or from inside a `*.ps1` script (even if you called from an interactive session).

Note: If these scenarios cannot be supported for technical reasons, (a) the cmdlet would ideally detect these scenarios and _refuse to run_ and (b) the limitation needs to be documented.

CLI example:

```powershell
# On Windows, from an elevated session on a machine that is set up for remoting.
# On Unix, set the machine up for SSH remoting and use -Hostname  instead of -ComputerName
pwsh -nop -c 'Enter-PSSession -ComputerName .; $host; exit'
```


### Expected behavior

An interactive remoting session (to the same machine) should be entered.

Only after manually exiting that session should `$host` and `exit` execute, in the _local_ session, at which point the `pwsh` call as a whole should terminate.


### Actual behavior

A remoting session is initiated, but _local processing continues instantly_; that is, the local commands following `Enter-PSSession` are _executed right away_, locally.

Because the `exit` then terminates the entire process, an interactive remote session is never entered.

If `exit` is omitted, the `pwsh` call _hangs_, and even <kbd>Ctrl-C</kbd> doesn't help (this doesn't happen with `powershell.exe`, which exits implicitly).

If, by contrast, you were to place  `Enter-PSSession -ComputerName .; $host` - without the `exit` - in a `*.ps1` file and were to execute that file from an interactive local session, `$host` would execute locally right away, and a remote session would be entered _only after the script terminates_.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-rc.1
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The reported behavior is by design.
labels.name: Resolution-By Design

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Rid of `TypeResolver.ResolveType()` call from `Process_Types_Ps1Xml()`.

Perf win at startup scenario is ~9%.

All static methods from SecurityDescriptorCommandsBase class are moved to new SecurityDescriptorCommandsHelperBase class in SMA. This allows to directly reference the static methods from  `Process_Types_Ps1Xml()`.

## PR Context

I was very surprised to discover that there is only one call of TypeResolver.ResolveType() in Process_Types_Ps1Xml which does the huge delay at startup scenario.

Before the PR:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22290914/139711138-dcd6319d-b7a3-4eb2-8b6c-d81bf1956787.png)

After the PR:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22290914/139711071-2e3afe58-dd7b-4997-a90d-25a75bfcbcd3.png)

-----
_In future I think it makes sense to improve a performance of TypeResolver.ResolveType() itself. While a cache is empty the method does very expensive assembly enumeration. I guess we could pre-build the cache at compile time for well-known assemblies and get perf wins for some scenarios._

-----

## PR Checklist

- [ ] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I would like to have a simple and concise method of suppressing errors and error messages, regardless of their type and source.

In a POSIX shell, I can do something like this:

```bash
set -e
rm nonexistent >/dev/null 2>&1 || : 
```

while this is not particularly beautiful, it works consistently. If anything, we should be able to do better in PowerShell.

This operator in PowerShell has different semantics based on `$ErrorActionPreference`, whether the command returns an exit code or throws an exception etc.. So using this idiom in PowerShell will not work. For example:

```powershell
$ErrorActionPreference = 'stop'
ri nonexistent *> $null || echo success
Remove-Item: Cannot find path 'C:\Users\rkitover\nonexistent' because it does not exist. 
```

in this case neither the error message is suppressed nor the alternate action is taken.

So, let's try something else:

```powershell
$ErrorActionPreference = 'stop'
try { ri nonexistent } catch {}; echo success
success
```

this is closest to what I want, with the caveat that the behavior still depends on `$ErrorActionPreference`, for example:

```powershell
$ErrorActionPreference = 'continue'
try { ri nonexistant } catch {}; echo success 
Remove-Item: Cannot find path 'C:\Users\rkitover\nonexistant' because it does not exist. 
success 
```

in this case the error message is not suppressed. So let's try another variant:

```powershell
$ErrorActionPreference = 'continue'
&{try { ri nonexistant } catch {}} *> $null; echo success
success
$ErrorActionPreference = 'stop'
&{try { ri nonexistant } catch {}} *> $null; echo success
success
```

this gives me consistent behavior regardless of `$ErrorActionPreference` and is the closest to what I'm trying to do in this case.

However, this is a pretty horrible construct.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

I am not a PowerShell expert so I don't know what the best design for a feature like this would be, I just want to be able to run a command, function, cmdlet, .NET code, or whatever, and suppress all error output and exceptions.

Also it would be nice if the `catch {}` block for a `try {}` was optional.

### Steps to reproduce

If during variable assignment you get an error (such as ItemNotFoundException), the variable will have weird behavior when used with -notlike and -notmatch operators (they will return false). Whereas even non-existent or null variables will behave normally (return true if used with -notlike and -notmatch).


### Expected behavior

```console
PS> $brokenVar = Get-Item "nonexistent"
PS> if ($brokenVar -notlike "pattern") { echo "true" } else { echo "false" }
true
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> $brokenVar = Get-Item "nonexistent"
PS> if ($brokenVar -notlike "pattern") { echo "true" } else { echo "false" }
false
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I would like the ability to cast from a hashtable using the constructor of a type, for example when no parameterless constructor is available but even if one is, using a '.ctor' key in the hashtable.

The '.ctor' key would be interpreted as an array and passed to the constructor of the type. I would expect similar if not identical behavior with this key's presence as observed using the `New-Object -ArgumentList $ConstructorParameters`.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

```
# Class definition used for functionality examples
class TestClass {
  hidden static [int]$NextId
  [int]$Id
  [string]$Name
  [object]$Payload
  # Because there is no parameterless constructor, currently this class cannot be instantiated by cast from a hashtable
  TestClass([string]$name) {
    $this.Id = ++[TestClass]::NextId
    $this.Name = $name
  }
}

# The three test cases below each construct the TestClass class and set the value of the Payload property

# TestCase1 demonstrates how we would do this currently (without New-Object)
$TestCase1 = [TestClass]::new("FirstTest")
$TestCase1.Payload = 1

# TestCase2 demonstrates how New-Object already supports this behavior
$TestCase2 = New-Object -TypeName TestClass -ArgumentList SecondTest -Property @{Payload  = 2}

# TestCase3 demonstrates how this operation would be performed using the '.ctor' hashtable key
$TestCase3  = [TestClass]@{
  '.ctor'   = @('ThirdTest')
  'Payload' = 3
}
```

labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

# Why submitted this issue?

I'm writing a powershell script to publish a .NET project, during this I need to get some useful infomation from the project file content, the content of project file is like this:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp3.1</TargetFramework>
    <AssemblyName>Sample.API</AssemblyName>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <PropertyGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)|$(Platform)'=='Debug|AnyCPU'">
    <NoWarn>1701;1702;1591;</NoWarn>
  </PropertyGroup>

</Project>
```

I want to get the `TargetFramework`, so I use this:

```powershell
$framework_name = ([xml](Get-Content .\Sample.API.csproj)).Project.PropertyGroup.TargetFramework
```

Then I need to use it, such as:

```powershell
$framework_name.ToUpper()
```

An error message appeared:

```plaintext
InvalidOperation: You cannot call a method on a null-valued expression.
```

Although in the end I reacted this is because I have two `PropertyGroups` of the same level and one of them does not have a attribute called `TargetFramework`, but it was really troublesome. 

The `$framework_name | gm` shows it is the `System.String`, `$framework_name.Count` is `2` and the second is null.

This script is a general publishing script, I have to assume that every attribute is like this, so every time when I need to get a attribute value, I must write code like this:

```powershell
($framework_name | Where-Object { $_ -ne $null }).ToLower()
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

# What is the suggestion?

I think the behavior of the above code should be the same as:

```powershell
$framework_name = ([xml](Get-Content .\Sample.API.csproj)).SelectNodes('Project/PropertyGroup/TargetFramework').InnerText
```

The `$framework_name.Count` is `1` and it will be very convenient to use

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I am desiring addition of support for uniform-resource-identifiers whose scheme is "file".

I am desiring addition of this because it shall enable usage of more consistent syntax during creation of software that should be invoked by operating-systems whose kernels are primarily comprised of code that is from NT, Unix, and Linux, respectively. (I am referring to "macOS", Windows 11, and "GNU" Software, when it is combined with Linux.)

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional) This functionality should be implemnted as one flag that should be "-Url" (for consistency with other commands that are for [PowerShell](http://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell)). It should be one alternative for "-Path". 
	SET-LOCATION -URL 'FILE://%SYSTEMDRIVE%/USERS'
[`FILE://%SYSTEMDRIVE%/WINDOWS/EXPLORER.EXE`](FILE://%SYSTEMDRIVE%/WINDOWS/EXPLORER.EXE) is already able to resolve the uniform-resource-identifier that has been proposed as demonstration of potential implementation my proposition.

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Fix #16293
Before #16165, we were using `InternalSymbolicLinkLinkCodeMethods.WinInternalGetTarget` to try resolving a possible link path, and that API never throws -- catch exception and returns null. However, `File.ResolveLinkTarget` throws when there is any error while resolving the link path, e.g. the file system doesn't support reparse point. This caused a regression in 7.2.0-rc1.

The fix is to wrap `File.ResolveLinkTarget` in a try/catch block, and use the original `fileName` when `ResolveLinkTarget` fails.

@iSazonov and @jborean93, thank you both for bring the regression to our attention, and also worked out the test.

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

WildcardPattern.Escape() does not escape `` ` ``, and as a result it's unreliable for escaping input for use in wildcard comparisons:

Define a string literal containing a single backtick character:

    $string = 'abc`def'

Create an escaped copy of the string value:

    $escaped = [WildcardPattern]::Escape($string)

Perform wildcard comparison and observe that it does not yield `$true` as expected:

    $string -like $escaped

(That is: `[WildcardPattern]::Escape($string)` should produce a string value equivalent to ```'abc``def'```, not return it as-is)

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> $string -like $escaped
True
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> $string -like $escaped
False
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

_No response_
